div.p: Greetings and blessings. I received your letters, esteemed brother, and understood what you request. I am indeed ready to assist you and your son; for this is deserved by your kindness towards me and your son's virtue. He brought with him truly excellent testimonials from England; but in what way your son can be helped and your otherwise large expenses reduced, I cannot easily say. I wish it were convenient for you to come to us sometime, and perhaps now to be present with us at the celebration of Charles; we could discuss this matter more intimately. And there is no need for you to seek another host than me; since my father-in-law has passed away to the Lord and my relative has changed residence, I do not see with whom you could lodge more comfortably than with me, your most devoted and loving friend.
Live and farewell happily with your whole family. In great haste, Zurich, January 22, 1552.
To the pious, well-learned, and faithful Mr. Hans Stumpf, pastor in Stammheim, his kind dear lord and brother.
